name: The Nexus of Higher Studies: Opportunities Abroad
description: Learn about opportunities for higher studies abroad in this two-day workshop.
venue: NS Lab, 2nd Floor, C Block, SRM IST VDP

name: INVENTUS
description: Showcase your innovation in our Hackathon, where your final project doesn't just win but earns a patent. Turn your groundbreaking ideas into intellectual property that makes an impact. Collaborate, create, and leave with a project that could shape the future.
rules: The hackathon is open to all students. Participants can join individually or form teams of up to 4 members. Registration is required before the deadline.
Participants must register online, submitting team names and member details. Any team member changes after registration must be communicated to the organizers.
The hackathon lasts 12 hours, with a theme announced at the start. Participants must develop projects based on the theme and present them to judges.
Integrity and honesty are required. Plagiarism, copying code, or unauthorized assistance will lead to immediate disqualification.
All projects must be submitted within the designated time frame through the provided platform. Functional projects meeting specified requirements are necessary for evaluation.
Projects will be evaluated on innovation, functionality, technical implementation, potential impact, and the quality of the presentation.
The winning project may be eligible for a patent, and top teams will receive cash prizes. All participants will get certificates of participation.
Teams can be disqualified for submitting copied code, disruptive behavior, or violating any event rules. Participants must bring their own hardware and adhere to the schedule.

name: Code Quest
description: CodeQuest is an adventure-themed quiz where participants embark on a journey through various realms of computer science and engineering. Each realm represents a different technical domain, and participants must answer questions to unlock the next realm and ultimately complete their quest.
fee: ₹120/- for a team of 2 participants, ₹180/- for a team of 3 participants, ₹220/- for a team of 4 participants
rules: The event is open to all students, allowing teams of two to four members.
The event will be offline with three coding rounds: code completion, error spotting, and writing code for a problem statement.
Participants must bring their laptops and adhere to time limits for each round, with increasing difficulty in problems across rounds.
Plagiarism, code copying, or seeking unauthorized help is strictly prohibited, leading to immediate disqualification.
Problem statements for each round will be provided, and participants must use specified programming languages to solve them.
Submissions must be error-free and submitted through the designated platform. Late submissions are only accepted for organizer-acknowledged technical issues.
Solutions are judged based on correctness, efficiency, code readability, and innovation, with bonus points for optimized solutions.

name: Block and Brawl
description: It is a two-round event blending strategic block and tackle techniques with high-stakes debate. Level 1 features and tactical challenges, while Level 2 focuses on applying strategies in competitive debates. Join us for an exciting blend of strategy, rhetoric, and networking.
rules: The topic is announced at the start of the debate. Participants may be given a few minutes to prepare their thoughts.

Participants must argue both 'for' and 'against' the given topic. The moderator will signal when to switch sides. The participant must immediately switch their stance and continue the debate from the opposite perspective.

Each side (for/against) is given a specific time to present their arguments, usually 30 seconds to 2 minutes per switch. The total time for the debate is also predetermined, typically around 5-10 minutes.

The moderator can call for a switch anytime. The number of switches is usually not fixed, adding an element of unpredictability. Participants must be prepared to switch their stance quickly and seamlessly.
Arguments should be clear, concise, and relevant. Participants should avoid repetition and instead provide new points with each switch.
Participants must maintain decorum and show respect for the opposing side's arguments. Interrupting or talking over the moderator or opponent is generally discouraged.
Clarity, fluency, and confidence in presenting arguments. Adaptability: Ability to switch sides quickly and effectively.
Keeping the audience and judges engaged through compelling arguments.

Round 1: All participants present their arguments on a given topic, with judges shortlisting the top contenders based on their reasoning, clarity, and ability to engage the audience.
Round 2: Only those who impress in this initial stage move forward to Round 2, where the real challenge begins.
Final Round: This final round determines the winners as the remaining debaters face off, switching sides and arguing both for and against the topic with agility when the command 'switch' is given.

name: Decision Making Through Data Analysis
description: Join us for a hands-on workshop on decision making through data analysis, where you'll dive into practical techniques and tools used in data-driven decision-making.
venue: NS Lab, 2nd Floor, C Block, SRM IST VDP
